text: [Applause] [Music] our rituals our culture is uh connected to this uh herum rice the her rice project is one of the seven uh variety projects of the Department of Agriculture in the the international rice research uh Institute in the absence of short-term projects like the heirloom project they could well be at risk of Disappearing this aom rise project is definitely a gift of the Philippines to the world [Music] I am Mrs anah habing of baranga am ganad I'm married with six children and I have also 12 grandchildren uh I am the leader of the farmer here in Aman it is a respect to our grandparents and without them we should not be what we are so we have to maintain the traditional rice This research project of Erie and uh the Department of Agriculture are of significant because it will empower the farmers get them organized so that they will attain that economies of the scale of late Market says that there is high demand for uh aom rice and it even command a higher price than the rice variety that cultivated in the lowland so there is a great opportunity for our uh farmers at the upand community to access uh the nich market which caters to uh [Music] rice there is an existing market and we believe that the market is even expanding we're trying to get the so-call geographical indication for specific um traditional varieties so this is like wine appellation where you can really identify a particular ular variety to a specific territory where it is originating from and this is very important for the farmers and for the consumer life because we can know we can trace where the products are coming from and who's growing the varieties and the location where the varieties are getting the traits that they are known for tourists are coming we are actually helping the lodging in the manawi hotel and we are helping people who are involved in the tourism activities we are helping them indirectly that's why I convince the farmers that we should also we should be active also and Revive Our custom and tradition in farming we return back our native rice we return back all the fishes the delicious uh foods that are growing in the rice field and sell it and sell it to the to the visitor so but while the other people are gaining from the tourist you are also gaining this arum rice project is a winwin win situation for Erie Erie got to learn more about this um Alum rice varieties particularly the traits the unique traits that they carry to the farmers because the farmers are getting will be getting more from their produce and they will be able to showcase their culture their tradition to the world and third to the consumers because they are going to get the health benefits and other important rats that these alom rice varieties can provide it is a win for the Philippines also for the country the value of these heirloom varieties comes from combining them with the communities where they have been traditionally grown the practices those communities have used for growing them their whole cultur is built around them and and those heirloom varieties are ESS central part of those communities their whole life whereas when you bring those varieties here into the gene Bank all we brought is the genetic material we haven't got the knowledge of those communities we haven't got the rest of the farming system that they're maintaining we've just got the genes what ought to happen is that we combine their knowledge with our knowledge and that would allow us to produce a package of improved varieties and improved agricultural methods that combine the best of both worlds in the Corda they own the seeds like you go from one family they have a selection of seeds that were passed on to them from generation to generation and you look at them and say like you're looking at the gem every grain that is sold really goes back to the farmers because the way that our our NGO and the market is set up is that there is a dividend sharing sharing to all the stakeholders the farmers the NGO and the and the consumer and so all of that plays into part when they sell the rice and they you buy the rise at the premium price if we lose the farmers if we lose the teres if we lose all these earlom grains we are poor what is Filipino food is what grows in our environment and what people do to it I want you to be feel that you're eating the Tera of this country you want to taste the Philippines you want to taste the food this grew from our land this was stealed by Philippine Farmers the DNA of these grains come from our forefathers [Music]
